name: Advanced MEC-as-a-Service
description:
Summary

  • MEC APIs integrate edge computing into apps, enabling developers to optimize tasks and services close to users. These APIs distribute workloads for mission-critical tasks, enhancing outcomes by selecting optimal network locations.
  • Telefónica linked APIs with AWS Wavelength Zone, letting developers merge AWS edge and specialized services. This partnership streamlines network-aware app creation, particularly for low-latency scenarios and validates Telefónica's improved connectivity and lower latency that aligns with GSMA's Open Gateway initiative for network API interoperability.
  • MEC-as-a-service is continuously evolving to add new concepts related to distributed DB-as-a-service (DBaaS), 3GPP SA6 Frameworks, session continuity for mobility, edge-to-cloud continuum.
  • The EDGEAPP architecture developed by 3GPP SA6 facilitates smooth communication between applications on user devices and dedicated servers positioned at the network's edge. This architectural approach guarantees the consistent operation of these servers across different network segments, enabling the provision of a wide range of services.
  • Session and service continuity enables dynamic application relocation and seamless transition and maintenance of user sessions as devices move between different edge nodes or network areas. Whereas edge to cloud continuum involves efficiently managing computing and network resources to ensure a balance between performance, security, and cost effectiveness in edge environments.
  • While the industry is currently investigating MEC APIs for various edge applications, other MEC-as-a-Service concepts are still in their early stages, with 3GPP standards being the primary focus at present. As the edge computing landscape develops and expands into critical, real-time, and advanced scenarios, emerging concepts including DBaaS, session continuity, EDGEAPP architecture, and the edge-to-cloud continuum will become more significant. Consequently, MEC-as-a-Service is positioned in the “Research” horizon.

name: Network-as-a-Service
description:
Summary

  • Traditional network setups involve significant upfront capital investment for physical infrastructure such as switches, routers, firewall appliances, and load balancers, making it challenging to keep up with emerging data-intensive applications. Network as a service (NaaS) offers a software-defined model where the network operator provides infrastructure and management as a service, allowing easy scalability and rapid deployment of new use cases from the cloud.
  • The telco industry has launched several NaaS-related initiatives with non-traditional telco bodies such as the Linux Foundation and projects including Anuket, Nephio, Sylva, and Camara that are focused on building a digital service architecture for telcos.
  • GSMA Open Gateway, a framework of network APIs, allows the developer community a universal access to operator networks. It simplifies multi-network global deployments, offering single points of access to multiple MNO network capabilities, and foster cost-efficient interoperability.
  • Deutsche Telekom and T-Mobile partnered to create T-DevEdge, a joint platform with APIs that offer global developers an easy access to telco network capabilities. One of the network APIs, Quality-on-Demand (QoD), is utilized by Siemens Energy for optimized remote maintenance using Microsoft's Azure cloud platform.
  • The telecom industry's pursuit of NaaS had been delayed by technology constraints, but it is now gaining momentum. Hardware vendors, telcos, cloud providers, and networking companies are all eyeing opportunities in this space. Despite challenges in standardization, performance, and scalability, NaaS holds a promising position in the industry's “Research” horizon.

Capgemini Capabilities

  • Capgemini recently worked with a major telco, a cloud company, and multiple network technology and software providers from radio to core, to build a proof of concept (PoC) for a disaggregated 5G network. The goal of the project was to prove that Network-as-a-Service (NaaS) was possible using multiple existing vendors and current standards. The project successfully launched, managed and closed multiple network slices, designed around real customer use cases.

name: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs)

Neuromorphic computing represents a paradigm shift in how we approach artificial intelligence
  • In Sep 2022, intel Labs launched a neuromorphic Kapoho Point board. Kapoho Point, a Loihi 2 neuromorphic chip-based board, is a compact system ideal for use in small form factor devices and applications ranging from drones to satellites and smart cars
